awd_titl_txt: Diffusion of Guests, Dopants, and Impurity Atoms Through Open Cage Allotropes of Si and Related Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description: There is a great need for development of next generation materials, derived from earth abundant elements, that would revolutionize the electronics industry for future generations of devices including computer chips, lasers, and detectors. Silicon is the second most abundant element on the Earth's crust and the most technologically significant. Many exotic forms of silicon, which exhibit caged or tunnel crystalline structures, hold the promise of high efficiency and low cost disruptive electronic and photonic properties that would push silicon to a new level. These exotic silicon structures, however, tend to form around ionic guest atoms. Their potential can be only realized with complete ionic guest removal. This research project addresses this vital requirement by elucidating the fundamental diffusion and mobility pathways for guest ions in silicon caged/tunnel structures and unraveling the complexities of the mechanistic pathways to guest diffusion. The research will create a fundamental understanding of ionic motion in open silicon structures that has not been achieved to-date. Closely integrated with the research are strong education and outreach programs to provide significant training and mentoring opportunities for undergraduate, graduate and underrepresented groups in materials science, including summer workshops and internship programs for undergraduate and high school students, and community outreach. The team also collaborates with the Rocky Mountain Camp for Dyslexic Kids to provide summer camps developed for students with dyslexia who have interest in and aptitude for science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM).

Technical Description: Many exotic forms of earth abundant silicon are theoretically predicted to have properties, such as a direct bandgap, that would revolutionize electronics and photonics industries. This potential has not been realized and the key limitation is the critical requirement of complete removal of the guest atoms around which these open crystal structures form. The ultimate goal of this project is to elucidate the ionic and atomic diffusional pathways and mobility of alkali and alkaline earth ions, inert guest atoms, and dopants in silicon caged and tunnel structures. Although there have been a number of exotic forms of silicon investigated via theory, simulation, and small-scale synthesis, a fundamental knowledge of the guest diffusion/mobility mechanisms is severely lacking. The major barrier that prohibits guest diffusion/mobility studies is the inability to produce sufficient quantities of phase pure material in thin-film, powder and bulk form. This barrier can be overcome by synthesis approach undertaken by the research team, allowing the research to explore: which guest diffusion pathways are preferable, i.e., via small or large cages, five-fold or six-fold rings of cages; the role of non-idealities, like vacancies, or impurities, and how partial occupancy and ion-ion interaction create unusual diffusion/solubility kinetics; the effect of charged versus neutral species and electron donation on diffusion. The research efforts include: synthesis and development of thin films and powders (on the grams-scale) of phase pure silicon allotropes with well-defined diffusive properties; investigation of macroscopic diffusion through the crystalline lattice of thin films of silicon allotropes; exploring the guest location/environment and dynamics, the defect impurities, and intrinsic defects in both films and powders. Key techniques include: time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectroscopy, electron spin resonance, and solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
As the second most abundant element on Earth, Si plays a central role in nearly all aspects of electronic devices. However, Si in the bulk, diamond-structured form (d-Si) has an indirect bandgap, weak absorption and inefficient light emission in the infrared range. Exotic forms of crystalline silicon that have been stabilized at ambient temperature and pressure include caged, open channel, and layered structures. Si clathrate is a cage-like, crystalline Si inclusion compound. Theoretical studies have predicted type II Si clathrate to have a direct or nearly direct bandgap, near 2.0 eV, making it an exciting alterative to d-Si in optoelectronic applications. Type II Si clathrates have been proposed as anodes for lithium-ion batteries. Lithiated clathrates are expected to exhibit excellent electrical conductivity due to the metallic behavior of clathrates. These properties make Si-Li clathrates potentially promising for electrochemical applications.

Realizing this potential requires the synthesis of type-II Si clathrates with Li in the cages and understanding of lithium-ion diffusion in the structure.Therefore, the major goal and outcome of this project has been to elucidate the ionic and atomic diffusional pathways and mobility of alkali and alkaline earth ions, inert guest atoms, and dopants in Si clathrates. The major barrier that has prohibited the latter guest diffusion/mobility studies has been the inability to produce sufficient quantities of phase pure material, or to produce materials in form factor (e.g., thin films) that optimizes diffusion. These barriers have been overcome by synthesis achievements by the project team, which therefore provided the team with the unique ability to advance this research.

At low guest concentration, Si clathrates can be viewed as novel Si-based semiconductors, with guest atoms acting as donors, potentially becoming an alternative to diamond-structured Si with disruptive optical and electronic properties. This project has developed a new fundamental study of the defect structures and guest properties in low guest concentration type II Si clathrate, revealing new understanding of the intrinsic optical properties of the clathrate film, and exploring alternative guest behavior in the clathrate structure.

Specifically, the major project outcomes include: (1) the discovery that the presence of the disordered Si defect in Si clathrate powders causes the thermally activated, hopping conductivity. (2) Na can act as a shallow donor in Si clathrate, with its donor electron extending onto the surrounding cages and interacting with the 29Si nuclei on the cages. (3) Na distribution in Si clathrate is inhomogeneous, forming Na dimers and clusters. (4) The optical properties of Si clathrate films are strongly affected by inhomogeneities and defect phases present mainly on the top surface and grain boundaries of the material. (5) Reactive ion etching and film exfoliation are effective methods to selectively remove the disordered defects in Si clathrate films. (6) Type II Si clathrate with low Na concentration is an optically efficient alternative crystalline form of Si that can transform Si-based applications in optoelectronics. (7) Li can be inserted into the nearly empty type II Si clathrate framework through thermal diffusion. (8) Li atoms inserted into the Si clathrate lattice can affect the stability of the system and donate electrons to the structure. (9) Li guests in Si clathrate are not simple analogs of Na guests. Li atoms tend to occupy clathrate cages doubly, forming pairs with other guest atoms.

From the extensive project outcomes, it is demonstrated that type II Si clathrate with tunable guest concentrations and species can be an alternative Si allotrope with exciting optoelectronic and spin properties that can facilitate disruptive applications.

The project team (PI, co-PI, students) developed during the project a series of hands-on activities providing fundamental knowledge on photons, fluorescence, and LEDs, and presented these at the Rocky Mountain Camp for Dyslexic Children in Colorado in 2019, 2021, 2022, 2023. They also developed the Lithography Hands-on Session for the 2020 SWEET for high school teachers with activities related to the energy transition and utilization. This online workshop was organized/hosted by the PI (during the COVID pandemic), involving scientists from the Colorado School of Mines, National Renewable Energy Lab, and STEM high school teachers, including schools with a significant underrepresented population. In-person SWEET workshops on renewable energy were organized/co-hosted by the PI in Summers 2021, 2022, 2023.
